content.body: I'm probably searching for the wrong keywords here. If you can use a record with Map and Set, why can't it be used as a key in a record? #{ #{ a: 1 }: 2 }?
The main spec complexity is that the spec would also need to define an ordering for R&T because their keys are sorted
content.formatted_body: The main spec complexity is that the spec would also need to define an ordering for R&T because their keys are sorted

content.body: I also imagine it would add considerable implementation complexity to allow more types as keys, relative to "only strings".
content.formatted_body: I also imagine it would add considerable implementation complexity to allow more types as keys, relative to "only strings".

content.body: It did come up in conversations, as it kind of provides a kind of immutable set. But overall did not seem motivated enough to include in the proposal, which was trying to be  maximally minimal
content.formatted_body: It did come up in conversations, as it kind of provides a kind of immutable set. But overall did not seem motivated enough to include in the proposal, which was trying to be  maximally minimal

content.body: yeah, not having a kind of sort is why there aren't sets or unordered tuples it seems. Just realized both ways would solve what I was trying. I was basically trying to use records as keys to make a set.
